title: 11 Best Sleeper Sofas & Sofa Beds That Are Truly Chic (2025)
author: Audrey Lee, Yelena Moroz Alpert
excerpt: The best sleeper sofas turn any living space into an impromptu bedroom. Our editors' list includes picks from Article, Benchmade, and beyond
text: All products featured on Architectural Digest are independently selected by our editors. By night, they can transform into comfortable lodging for family, friends, or weary visitors who’ve stopped by for a sleepover. And while you may not think of them as the sexiest furnishings on the market, we’re here to respectfully disagree. The gel-infused memory foam mattress is “a real upgrade” from the typical sleeper mattresses of the past that tend to be lacking in the support department “My son had to use the sleeper for almost a week because we were doing renovations in his bedroom, and he said it was better than his regular mattress,” Alpert, who has the sofa in olive green performance velvet, says. “The color works as a neutral that has personality, and reads as a soft, almost sage-like hue,” she explains. But if you want to go a bit bolder, the Shelter sleeper is also available in wildcard picks like orange and yellow. While you can punch up the color, this probably isn’t a couch that will match your freak if you want something more out-there.When it comes to delivery, the couch did take about eight weeks to make as it was a made-to-order upholstery option. But Alpert notes that the West Elm customer service and delivery process is excellent, as she was able to schedule the delivery around her renovation. What’s more, when it was at her house, the delivery team took it upstairs no problem and even made it fit through her 29-inch doorways.Read the full review here.Serta Durango Convertible Sleeper SofaDimensionsRegular: 34.3'' H X 86'' W X 42.1'' DPulled-out: 34.3'' H x 79.1"W x 60"DMaterialsPolyester upholstery (Brown, Ivory, White)Pocketed coil springsShipping: Room of Choice–item placed in any room in your homeReturn Policy: Within 30 days of deliveryUpsides:Soft fabricEasy to pull out, one-hand operationWood sled base adds stabilityDownsides:Only White colorway is in stockWhite fabric can get scuffedAssembly requiredIt’s always a good sign when a sleeper sofa is from a company that knows mattresses. The Serta Durango convertible sleeper has dual coils, and pocketed high-quality springs for extra comfort. When you’re ready, the pull-out seats turn into a queen-sized bed. Thanks to its finger guard technology, your fingers are also safe from pinching. We also love that its space-saving size and clean lines (the sleeper is anchored by a wood sled base) fit comfortably in a modern home with a minimalist style. Made-to-order items are not eligible.Upsides:Solid wood frameSoft upholsteryEasy to grab handlesDownsides:No separate mattress or cushioningNot all futons need to look like they belong in a college dorm room. This option from West Elm is as attractive as any standard love seat or sofa, while still easily converting to a queen-sized bed. Subtle handles allow for an easy pull-out, and additional legs on both sides add stability. Unlike the traditional futons of the early aughts, which have a separate frame from the cushion, this is an all-in-one model that’s virtually indistinguishable from a regular couch—no cushion sliding or bulky frame in sight.What to Consider When Buying a Sleeper SofaWhat kind of a sleeper sofa are you looking for?There are three main types of sleeper sofas in the world: Futon-style couches (like the are a less bulky and heavy option where the cushions of the couch fold down to become a surface for sleeping. Pull-out couches are the most traditional and also the heaviest, as they contain a full mattress within an inner cavity, combined with the couch itself. For those, you’ll probably want to request white-glove delivery if you can afford it, as they’ll require some huffing and puffing to transport it into your house. Technically a long chaise or daybed can also function as sleeper sofas, but since those could fall into a separate category, we mostly tested the two former options for this story.How much room do you have in your home?Space is one of the biggest considerations you'll have to weigh when you’re shopping for couches. Depending on the size of your guest room, you may have the square footage for a sprawling pull-out style couch, or need to make do with a fold-down futon for an area with a smaller footprint. Always, always, always measure the designated space you want to slot your new couch (along with your doors!) before trying to squeeze something past the threshold of your home that just won't fit.How much support do you need?Compared to, say, an air mattress (which can be saggy and provide uneven support), a sleeper sofa is typically going to be much more comfortable for your guests to sleep on. It all boils down to the kind of sleeper you are and what support you value, though. Some sleepers might prefer a couch without the dreaded support bar propping up the bed in a pull-out sofa, while others need a real springs-and-all mattress rather than a bricklike futon to lay back on. Consider what types of support you might need in our primer on how to shop for a mattress.How We TestedThere are many factors that went into each of our reviews to give you the insight you need to select the best sleeper sofa for your home. Here's a peek at our thought process for these standardized reviews we run:Ordering and Customization Process: Price points, shallow or deep seats, armrests or armless, down seat and back cushions or foam cushioning, and which upholstery to choose—each of the sofas we tested has possibilities. We also documented the lead times and expected delivery timelines for each model.Couch Delivery and Assembly: Curbside or white-glove delivery, fully assembled or DIY. And, if DIY, how many pieces did the sofa arrive in, and how difficult was the assembly?After Installation: We asked some tough functionality questions of each sofa: Is it practical for a modern home? Is the couch kid and/or pet friendly? What are the care and cleaning instructions? And did it look better in real life than in the photos?Pullout Process: We wanted to know just how easy it is to turn these sofas into makeshift mattresses. We asked our testers how difficult it was to figure out how to convert their seats to sleeper mode and how much physical strength it required.Sleep Test: The big question we wanted to answer: Just how well can you sleep on a sleeper sofa? We grilled our testers on what it’s actually like to spend multiple nights snoozing on these bad boys. How plush or firm did the pullout mattress feel? What was the mattress type? Does the couch easily convert into sleeper mode? Is it actually comfortable?How We ChoseOn our pursuit for the perfect sleeper sofa, we prioritized picks that were above all comfortable to sleep on, plus elegant enough to suit our testers’ aesthetics (anything that didn’t make at least a B- for all of the criteria above was not mentioned in our piece at all). Our top choices were also couches that shipped out quickly and weren’t a complete nightmare to set up, factoring in that more custom pieces could take slightly longer to produce).Over the years since we first started testing out sleeper sofas, we delisted picks from brands like EQ3 and Apt. 2B that felt overly cost-prohibitive for the quality, and anything else that was no longer in stock. And because we haven’t had the chance to test out every iteration of sleeper sofa on the market just yet, we included a section of alternative picks for shoppers that our team is either in the process of testing right now or that we think you should know about based on style and brand reputation.What Are the Best Sleeper Sofas for Small Spaces?Small spaces, while defined by a small footprint, can also be surprisingly adept at accommodating different types of seating depending on your layout. It’s why experts like designer Caroline Burke of Anna Burke Interiors recommend sectionals even in small apartments for their versatility. “A sectional can give you that maxed-out seating and help the room feel like a cozy nook, not a cramped back office,” she previously told us.You may also be concerned about space if you’re thinking about a sleeper sofa with an internal pullout bed for guests. Not only do you need to think about the dimensions of the couch itself, but also how much room you have for an internal bed. Always be sure to measure before calling in any larger furnishings to your home (which can be a pain to box up for returns), and consider a futon-style bed like the Teddy Sleeper sofa above or the slim, streamlined Carmel Daybed from Pottery Barn if you’re really tight on square footage. Companies like Burrow also sell Sleep Kits that can convert a regular couch surface into a sleeper, complete with a small cushy topper, sheets, pillow, and beyond.How Do You Style a Multipurpose Guest Nook?Oftentimes, people who don’t have the budget for separate office and guest rooms will combine the two into a multifunctional live-work space. If that sounds like you, consider these pro tips from AD PRO Directory members who have previously weighed in with design advice for guest rooms.“When selecting [a guest room sofa], be careful that it is both comfortable to sit on and sleep on,” New York-City based designer Paris Forino previously told us. In a Greenwich Village town house project she decorated where an office served as a transitional sitting room and guest bedroom, she created a custom sleeper sofa with velveteen upholstery and plush cushions plus a comfortable mattress inside.In these transitional spaces, incorporating elements of a bedroom and an office, such as bookshelves and blackout shades, can also help a room wear multiple hats. Textured accents like throw pillows and calming color palettes are other suggestions designers like Sara Swabb, the founder and creative director of Storie Collective in Washington, DC, recommend for a space where guests will drift off.Don’t Sleep on More Seat Week Content:Check out a few AD classics that’ll help you sit back and relax.AD’s Seat Week: An essential furniture guide to the best sofas, sectionals, chairs, and moreThe Best Office Chairs: Ergonomic picks tested and reviewed from Herman Miller, Knoll, Amazon, and moreThe Very Best Sectional Sofas, Tested and Reviewed: We shipped the top sectional sofas—left and right chaises, armless, modular, and MCM models from burrow, pottery barn, west Elm, and more—into the homes of Clever contributors to test them firsthandBest Affordable Couch Options That Don’t Skimp on Style: We scoured the internet for beautifully designed couches, all under $2,000Best Leather Sofas for Stylish Spaces: We’re breaking leather sofas out of the bachelor pad starter kitBest Outdoor Sofas to Define Your Exterior Space: Seats and recliners for a poolside oasis, shade-laden backyard, or tight-fitting balcony

What to Consider When Buying a Sleeper Sofa

What kind of a sleeper sofa are you looking for?

There are three main types of sleeper sofas in the world: Futon-style couches (like the are a less bulky and heavy option where the cushions of the couch fold down to become a surface for sleeping. Pull-out couches are the most traditional and also the heaviest, as they contain a full mattress within an inner cavity, combined with the couch itself. For those, you’ll probably want to request white-glove delivery if you can afford it, as they’ll require some huffing and puffing to transport it into your house. Technically a long chaise or daybed can also function as sleeper sofas, but since those could fall into a separate category, we mostly tested the two former options for this story.

How much room do you have in your home?

Space is one of the biggest considerations you'll have to weigh when you’re shopping for couches. Depending on the size of your guest room, you may have the square footage for a sprawling pull-out style couch, or need to make do with a fold-down futon for an area with a smaller footprint. Always, always, always measure the designated space you want to slot your new couch (along with your doors!) before trying to squeeze something past the threshold of your home that just won't fit.

How much support do you need?

Compared to, say, an air mattress (which can be saggy and provide uneven support), a sleeper sofa is typically going to be much more comfortable for your guests to sleep on. It all boils down to the kind of sleeper you are and what support you value, though. Some sleepers might prefer a couch without the dreaded support bar propping up the bed in a pull-out sofa, while others need a real springs-and-all mattress rather than a bricklike futon to lay back on. Consider what types of support you might need in our primer on how to shop for a mattress.

How We Tested

There are many factors that went into each of our reviews to give you the insight you need to select the best sleeper sofa for your home. Here's a peek at our thought process for these standardized reviews we run:

Ordering and Customization Process: Price points, shallow or deep seats, armrests or armless, down seat and back cushions or foam cushioning, and which upholstery to choose—each of the sofas we tested has possibilities. We also documented the lead times and expected delivery timelines for each model.

Couch Delivery and Assembly: Curbside or white-glove delivery, fully assembled or DIY. And, if DIY, how many pieces did the sofa arrive in, and how difficult was the assembly?

After Installation: We asked some tough functionality questions of each sofa: Is it practical for a modern home? Is the couch kid and/or pet friendly? What are the care and cleaning instructions? And did it look better in real life than in the photos?

Pullout Process: We wanted to know just how easy it is to turn these sofas into makeshift mattresses. We asked our testers how difficult it was to figure out how to convert their seats to sleeper mode and how much physical strength it required.

Sleep Test: The big question we wanted to answer: Just how well can you sleep on a sleeper sofa? We grilled our testers on what it’s actually like to spend multiple nights snoozing on these bad boys. How plush or firm did the pullout mattress feel? What was the mattress type? Does the couch easily convert into sleeper mode? Is it actually comfortable?

How We Chose

On our pursuit for the perfect sleeper sofa, we prioritized picks that were above all comfortable to sleep on, plus elegant enough to suit our testers’ aesthetics (anything that didn’t make at least a B- for all of the criteria above was not mentioned in our piece at all). Our top choices were also couches that shipped out quickly and weren’t a complete nightmare to set up, factoring in that more custom pieces could take slightly longer to produce).

Over the years since we first started testing out sleeper sofas, we delisted picks from brands like EQ3 and Apt. 2B that felt overly cost-prohibitive for the quality, and anything else that was no longer in stock. And because we haven’t had the chance to test out every iteration of sleeper sofa on the market just yet, we included a section of alternative picks for shoppers that our team is either in the process of testing right now or that we think you should know about based on style and brand reputation.

What Are the Best Sleeper Sofas for Small Spaces?

Small spaces, while defined by a small footprint, can also be surprisingly adept at accommodating different types of seating depending on your layout. It’s why experts like designer Caroline Burke of Anna Burke Interiors recommend sectionals even in small apartments for their versatility. “A sectional can give you that maxed-out seating and help the room feel like a cozy nook, not a cramped back office,” she previously told us.

You may also be concerned about space if you’re thinking about a sleeper sofa with an internal pullout bed for guests. Not only do you need to think about the dimensions of the couch itself, but also how much room you have for an internal bed. Always be sure to measure before calling in any larger furnishings to your home (which can be a pain to box up for returns), and consider a futon-style bed like the Teddy Sleeper sofa above or the slim, streamlined Carmel Daybed from Pottery Barn if you’re really tight on square footage. Companies like Burrow also sell Sleep Kits that can convert a regular couch surface into a sleeper, complete with a small cushy topper, sheets, pillow, and beyond.

How Do You Style a Multipurpose Guest Nook?

Oftentimes, people who don’t have the budget for separate office and guest rooms will combine the two into a multifunctional live-work space. If that sounds like you, consider these pro tips from AD PRO Directory members who have previously weighed in with design advice for guest rooms.

“When selecting [a guest room sofa], be careful that it is both comfortable to sit on and sleep on,” New York-City based designer Paris Forino previously told us. In a Greenwich Village town house project she decorated where an office served as a transitional sitting room and guest bedroom, she created a custom sleeper sofa with velveteen upholstery and plush cushions plus a comfortable mattress inside.

In these transitional spaces, incorporating elements of a bedroom and an office, such as bookshelves and blackout shades, can also help a room wear multiple hats. Textured accents like throw pillows and calming color palettes are other suggestions designers like Sara Swabb, the founder and creative director of Storie Collective in Washington, DC, recommend for a space where guests will drift off.
